### Tidelands & Water Rights

**Tideland Ownership:**
The property includes tidelands extending to the line of mean low tide, as described in historical deeds dating back to the 1950s.

**Historical Tideland Deed Information:**

**Statutory Warranty Deed (November 13, 1954)**
- **Grantor:** J. Verne Shangle and Ruth Shangle, his wife
- **Grantee:** Norton Clapp and Jane B. Clapp, his wife
- **Consideration:** $10.00
- **Recording:** Escrow No. 51049-H3, LTI Order SJ 949
- **Date Recorded:** November 25, 1954
- **Location:** San Juan County, Washington
- **Executed In:** Multnomah County, Oregon
- **Document Images:** Tideland_Deed_Page1.jpg, Tideland_Deed_Page2.jpg

**Tideland Parcels Description:**
The tideland deed describes approximately **12 acres of land** in Government Lot Four (4), Section Eight (8), Township Thirty-six (36) North, Range Two (2) W.W.M., including:

- Land in the southeast corner of the northeast quarter of Section Seven (7)
- South one half of southwest quarter of southeast quarter
- Multiple parcels of first class uplands
- Second class tidelands extending to the line of mean low tide

**Detailed Metes and Bounds:**
The deed includes five (5) separately described parcels with detailed metes and bounds descriptions using:
- Section lines and corners as reference points
- Distances measured in feet and chains
- Bearings and directions from established survey points
- Meander corners and section corners as beginning points

**Subject To:**
- **Statutory Reservations:** Contained in Deed recorded in Volume 17 of Deeds, Page 50, from the State of Washington (as grantor) to John Lawson (as grantee)
- **Road Easements:** Numerous grants of easements for road purposes (not definitively described)
- **Boundary Questions:** Question of the location of the lateral boundaries of said Tide Lands
- **State Reservations:** Standard Washington State tideland reservations apply

**Current Tideland Status:**
- Tidelands are noted in parcel legal descriptions as "TDS" (Tidelands)
- Parcel 260833008000 (Four Winds Westward Ho - neighbor) includes "20.13 CHS TDS" (20.13 chains of tidelands)
- Your waterfront parcels (260833006000, 260833007000) likely include tideland rights
- Exact extent of current tideland ownership should be verified with title documents

**Waterfront Access:**
- **Waterfront Parcels:** 260833006000 (23.74 acres), 260833007000 (5.06 acres)
- **Shoreline Jurisdiction:** 200-foot buffer from top of bank designated as Rural Forest
- **Water Body:** [Specify bay, sound, or water body name]
- **Shoreline Length:** [To be measured]

**Water Rights:**
- **Wells:** [Document well locations and permits]
- **Water Source:** [Municipal, well, or other]
- **Water Quality:** [Testing results and dates]
- **Riparian Rights:** Property includes riparian rights associated with waterfront parcels

**Regulatory Considerations:**
- San Juan County Shoreline Master Program applies to waterfront parcels
- Washington State Department of Natural Resources regulates state-owned aquatic lands
- Hydraulic Project Approval (HPA) required for work below ordinary high water mark
- Shoreline Substantial Development Permits may be required for docks, bulkheads, or other shoreline modifications

**Recommended Actions:**
- Obtain current title report to verify extent of tideland ownership
- Review original deed chain to Norton Clapp and subsequent transfers
- Survey tideland boundaries if planning waterfront development
- Consult with San Juan County and WA DNR regarding tideland use and development rights

### Maps & Surveys
- **Survey Date:** [Date]

- **Map Location:** [File location or physical storage]
- **Topographical Features:** [Description]
- **Tideland Deed Documents:** Tideland_Deed_Page1.jpg, Tideland_Deed_Page2.jpg (historical warranty deed from 1954)

### Zoning & Land Use

**Land Use Designations:**
- **FOR (Forest Resource):** Parcels 260833007000, 260833006000, 260741010000, 260741007000, 260741011000, 260743008000, 260743010000

**Shoreline Buffer Designation:**
- **Rural Forest:** Applies within 200 feet from top of bank on waterfront parcels
- **Waterfront Parcels:** 260833006000, 260833007000
- **Buffer Purpose:** Protects shoreline ecology and water quality while allowing limited rural uses

**Governing Code:**
- **San Juan County Code 18.30.040** - Land Use Table for Rural, Resource, and Special Land Use Designations
- **Reference:** https://www.codepublishing.com/WA/SanJuanCounty/html/SanJuanCounty18/SanJuanCounty1830.html
- **Purpose:** Establishes which land uses are allowed, require permits, or are prohibited based on land use designation

**Use Classification System:**
- **Y** = Allowed outright (no project permit required)
- **P** = Provisional use permit required (administrative review)
- **P/C** = Provisional or Conditional use (administrator determines)
- **C** = Conditional use permit required (public hearing)
- **N** = Prohibited

**Conservation Easements:**
- Multiple parcels include conservation easements (noted as "TGW CONS ESMT" in legal descriptions)
- Conservation easements may further restrict uses beyond land use designation requirements
- Parcels with easements: 260833007000, 260833006000, 260741010000, 260741007000, 260741011000, 260743008000, 260743010000

**Current Use Classification:**
- Property enrolled in current use program with significantly reduced current use values
- Current use taxation provides property tax relief for resource lands

**Permitted Uses:**
- Refer to San Juan County Code Table 18.30.040 for complete list of allowed uses by designation
- Common allowed uses in FO and RFF designations include: residential dwellings, agriculture, forestry, accessory structures
- Some commercial and recreational uses may require conditional or provisional use permits
- Consult San Juan County Community Development Department for specific use determinations

**Additional Regulations:**
- Chapter 18.60 SJCC - Development Standards
- Chapter 18.40 SJCC - Performance and Use-Specific Standards
- Chapter 18.80 SJCC - Permit Procedures
- San Juan County Shoreline Master Program (for waterfront parcels)
- Any applicable overlay districts or subarea plans

**Restrictions:**
- Conservation easements apply to multiple parcels
- Shoreline regulations apply to waterfront parcels (260833006000, 260833007000)
- Development must comply with critical areas ordinances
- Building permits and land use permits required for most development activities

subsections.intro: The property is surrounded by various neighbors, ranging from individual homeowners to corporate entities. Below is a comprehensive list of adjacent and nearby properties.

subsections.title: Tidelands & Water Rights
subsections.content:
**Tideland Ownership:**
The property includes tidelands extending to the line of mean low tide, as described in historical deeds dating back to the 1950s.

**Historical Tideland Deed Information:**

**Statutory Warranty Deed (November 13, 1954)**
- **Grantor:** J. Verne Shangle and Ruth Shangle, his wife
- **Grantee:** Norton Clapp and Jane B. Clapp, his wife
- **Consideration:** $10.00
- **Recording:** Escrow No. 51049-H3, LTI Order SJ 949
- **Date Recorded:** November 25, 1954
- **Location:** San Juan County, Washington
- **Executed In:** Multnomah County, Oregon
- **Document Images:** Tideland_Deed_Page1.jpg, Tideland_Deed_Page2.jpg

**Tideland Parcels Description:**
The tideland deed describes approximately **12 acres of land** in Government Lot Four (4), Section Eight (8), Township Thirty-six (36) North, Range Two (2) W.W.M., including:

- Land in the southeast corner of the northeast quarter of Section Seven (7)
- South one half of southwest quarter of southeast quarter
- Multiple parcels of first class uplands
- Second class tidelands extending to the line of mean low tide

**Detailed Metes and Bounds:**
The deed includes five (5) separately described parcels with detailed metes and bounds descriptions using:
- Section lines and corners as reference points
- Distances measured in feet and chains
- Bearings and directions from established survey points
- Meander corners and section corners as beginning points

**Subject To:**
- **Statutory Reservations:** Contained in Deed recorded in Volume 17 of Deeds, Page 50, from the State of Washington (as grantor) to John Lawson (as grantee)
- **Road Easements:** Numerous grants of easements for road purposes (not definitively described)
- **Boundary Questions:** Question of the location of the lateral boundaries of said Tide Lands
- **State Reservations:** Standard Washington State tideland reservations apply

**Current Tideland Status:**
- Tidelands are noted in parcel legal descriptions as "TDS" (Tidelands)
- Parcel 260833008000 (Four Winds Westward Ho - neighbor) includes "20.13 CHS TDS" (20.13 chains of tidelands)
- Your waterfront parcels (260833006000, 260833007000) likely include tideland rights
- Exact extent of current tideland ownership should be verified with title documents

**Waterfront Access:**
- **Waterfront Parcels:** 260833006000 (23.74 acres), 260833007000 (5.06 acres)
- **Shoreline Jurisdiction:** 200-foot buffer from top of bank designated as Rural Forest
- **Water Body:** [Specify bay, sound, or water body name]
- **Shoreline Length:** [To be measured]

**Water Rights:**
- **Wells:** [Document well locations and permits]
- **Water Source:** [Municipal, well, or other]
- **Water Quality:** [Testing results and dates]
- **Riparian Rights:** Property includes riparian rights associated with waterfront parcels

**Regulatory Considerations:**
- San Juan County Shoreline Master Program applies to waterfront parcels
- Washington State Department of Natural Resources regulates state-owned aquatic lands
- Hydraulic Project Approval (HPA) required for work below ordinary high water mark
- Shoreline Substantial Development Permits may be required for docks, bulkheads, or other shoreline modifications

**Recommended Actions:**
- Obtain current title report to verify extent of tideland ownership
- Review original deed chain to Norton Clapp and subsequent transfers
- Survey tideland boundaries if planning waterfront development
- Consult with San Juan County and WA DNR regarding tideland use and development rights

subsections.title: Zoning & Land Use
subsections.content:
**Land Use Designations:**
- **FOR (Forest Resource):** Parcels 260833007000, 260833006000, 260741010000, 260741007000, 260741011000, 260743008000, 260743010000

**Shoreline Buffer Designation:**
- **Rural Forest:** Applies within 200 feet from top of bank on waterfront parcels
- **Waterfront Parcels:** 260833006000, 260833007000
- **Buffer Purpose:** Protects shoreline ecology and water quality while allowing limited rural uses

**Governing Code:**
- **San Juan County Code 18.30.040** - Land Use Table for Rural, Resource, and Special Land Use Designations
- **Reference:** https://www.codepublishing.com/WA/SanJuanCounty/html/SanJuanCounty18/SanJuanCounty1830.html
- **Purpose:** Establishes which land uses are allowed, require permits, or are prohibited based on land use designation

**Use Classification System:**
- **Y** = Allowed outright (no project permit required)
- **P** = Provisional use permit required (administrative review)
- **P/C** = Provisional or Conditional use (administrator determines)
- **C** = Conditional use permit required (public hearing)
- **N** = Prohibited

**Conservation Easements:**
- Multiple parcels include conservation easements (noted as "TGW CONS ESMT" in legal descriptions)
- Conservation easements may further restrict uses beyond land use designation requirements
- Parcels with easements: 260833007000, 260833006000, 260741010000, 260741007000, 260741011000, 260743008000, 260743010000

**Current Use Classification:**
- Property enrolled in current use program with significantly reduced current use values
- Current use taxation provides property tax relief for resource lands

**Permitted Uses:**
- Refer to San Juan County Code Table 18.30.040 for complete list of allowed uses by designation
- Common allowed uses in FO and RFF designations include: residential dwellings, agriculture, forestry, accessory structures
- Some commercial and recreational uses may require conditional or provisional use permits
- Consult San Juan County Community Development Department for specific use determinations

**Additional Regulations:**
- Chapter 18.60 SJCC - Development Standards
- Chapter 18.40 SJCC - Performance and Use-Specific Standards
- Chapter 18.80 SJCC - Permit Procedures
- San Juan County Shoreline Master Program (for waterfront parcels)
- Any applicable overlay districts or subarea plans

**Restrictions:**
- Conservation easements apply to multiple parcels
- Shoreline regulations apply to waterfront parcels (260833006000, 260833007000)
- Development must comply with critical areas ordinances
- Building permits and land use permits required for most development activities

#### Appliance & System Lifespan and Replacement Schedule

This section provides industry-standard expected lifespans for all major appliances and systems in the Main House. Use this as a planning guide for budgeting future replacements and scheduling preventive maintenance.

**HVAC Systems:**

| System | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|--------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Oil Furnace | 15-20 years | Plan replacement at 18-20 years | Annual professional service required; clean/replace filters quarterly |
| Electric Water Heater | 8-12 years | Plan replacement at 10-12 years | Flush tank annually; check anode rod every 3-5 years; inspect for leaks regularly |
| Thermostat (Programmable) | 10-15 years | Replace when malfunctioning or upgrading HVAC | Replace batteries annually (if applicable) |

**Your Equipment:** Furnace (West Zone) Thermo Pride - *Expected 15-20 years*; Furnace (East Zone) Thermo Pride - *Expected 15-20 years*; Water Heater (Main) Bradford White 50 gal - *Expected 10-12 years*; Water Heater (Basement) Bradford White 50 gal - *Expected 10-12 years*

**Kitchen Appliances:**

| Appliance | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|-----------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Refrigerator | 10-18 years | Plan replacement at 13-15 years | Clean condenser coils every 6 months; check door seals annually |
| Range/Stove (Dual Fuel) | 15-23 years | Plan replacement at 18-20 years | Clean burners regularly; professional service as needed |
| Dishwasher | 9-12 years | Plan replacement at 10-12 years | Clean filter monthly; run with dishwasher cleaner quarterly |
| Microwave | 9-10 years | Plan replacement at 9-10 years | Clean interior regularly; test door seal annually |

**Your Equipment:** Refrigerator (Entry) Hotpoint - *Expected 10-15 years*; Refrigerator (Kitchen) KitchenAid Built-in - *Expected 13-18 years (premium)*; Range GE Monogram 48" - *Expected 18-23 years (professional-grade)*; Dishwasher - *Expected 10-12 years*; Microwave Sharp Carousel - *Expected 9-10 years*

**Laundry Appliances:**

| Appliance | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|-----------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Washing Machine (Front-load) | 10-14 years | Plan replacement at 12-14 years | Clean gasket monthly; leave door open between uses; check hoses annually |
| Dryer (Electric) | 10-13 years | Plan replacement at 12-13 years | Clean lint trap after every use; clean vent annually |

**Your Equipment:** Washer Maytag MFWN9700SQ1 - *Expected 12-14 years*; Dryer Maytag MEDZ600SD0 - *Expected 12-13 years*

**Electrical & Security Systems:**

| System | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|--------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Electrical Panel | 25-40 years | Inspect at 25 years; replace if outdated | Professional inspection every 3-5 years |
| Security Alarm System | 10-15 years | Upgrade at 12-15 years | Test monthly; replace batteries annually |
| Router/Modem | 3-5 years | Replace every 4-5 years | Update firmware regularly |
| Irrigation Controller | 5-10 years | Replace at 8-10 years | Check batteries seasonally; test zones annually |

**Your Equipment:** Pushmatic Panels - *Vintage system, consider upgrade*; Square D Panels - *Expected 30-40 years*; Security Alarm Honeywell - *Expected 12-15 years*; Router Zhone - *Expected 4-5 years*; Irrigation Rain Bird - *Expected 8-10 years*

**Replacement Planning Guidelines:**

Replace (rather than repair) when: (1) Repair costs exceed 50% of replacement cost, (2) Appliance is beyond 75% of expected lifespan, (3) Energy efficiency improvements would save significant costs, or (4) Multiple repairs in past 2 years.

**Budget Planning - Estimated Replacement Costs:**
- Water Heaters (2): Every 10-12 years (~$1,500-$2,500 each installed)
- Furnaces (2): Every 15-20 years (~$3,000-$6,000 each installed)
- Refrigerators (2): Every 13-15 years (~$1,500-$8,000 depending on model)
- Range: Every 18-20 years (~$5,000-$15,000 for professional-grade)
- Washer/Dryer: Every 12-13 years (~$1,200-$2,000 for the pair)
- Dishwasher: Every 10-12 years (~$800-$1,500 installed)
- Microwave: Every 9-10 years (~$200-$500)

**Maintenance Schedule Summary:**

**Monthly:** Test security alarm; clean dishwasher filter; clean dryer lint trap; clean washer gasket

**Quarterly:** Clean/replace furnace filters; run dishwasher cleaner cycle; test irrigation zones

**Semi-Annually:** Clean refrigerator condenser coils; check irrigation batteries

**Annually:** Professional furnace service; flush water heater tanks; check water heater anode rods (every 3-5 years); professional alarm service; clean dryer vent; check washer hoses; test GFCI/AFCI breakers; professional electrical inspection (every 3-5 years)

- **Generator:** Dayton diesel generator (documented in Generator Shed section)
- **Buildings Served:** Main House, Chalet, Camp Kitchen

- **Switch Locations:** "House Main Switch #1", "Main Switch on panel #2", "Transfer Switch #3"
- **Operating Instructions:** Complete procedure for switching between OPALCO utility power and generator power
- **Photos:** Generator_Transfer_Switch_Instructions.jpg
- **Critical Note:** Manual transfer switch requires sequential steps to safely switch between utility and generator power

**Transfer Switch Operating Procedure:**

*To switch to generator power:*
1. Start generator
2. Turn off House Main Switch #1
3. Turn off main Switch on panel #2
4. Switch #3 Transfer Switch to GEN.SE (generator)
5. Turn on House Main Switch #1
6. Turn on main switch on panel #2

*To switch back to OPALCO utility power:*
1. Turn off House Main Switch #1
2. Turn off main Switch on panel #2
3. Switch #3 Transfer Switch to OPALCO
4. Turn off generator
5. Turn on House Main Switch #1
6. Turn on main switch on panel #2

- Manual generator transfer switch

#### Appliance & System Lifespan and Replacement Schedule

This section provides industry-standard expected lifespans for all major appliances and systems in the Main House. Use this as a planning guide for budgeting future replacements and scheduling preventive maintenance.

**HVAC Systems:**

| System | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|--------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Oil Furnace | 15-20 years | Plan replacement at 18-20 years | Annual professional service required; clean/replace filters quarterly |
| Electric Water Heater | 8-12 years | Plan replacement at 10-12 years | Flush tank annually; check anode rod every 3-5 years; inspect for leaks regularly |
| Thermostat (Programmable) | 10-15 years | Replace when malfunctioning or upgrading HVAC | Replace batteries annually (if applicable) |

**Your Equipment:** Furnace (West Zone) Thermo Pride - *Expected 15-20 years*; Furnace (East Zone) Thermo Pride - *Expected 15-20 years*; Water Heater (Main) Bradford White 50 gal - *Expected 10-12 years*; Water Heater (Basement) Bradford White 50 gal - *Expected 10-12 years*

**Kitchen Appliances:**

| Appliance | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|-----------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Refrigerator | 10-18 years | Plan replacement at 13-15 years | Clean condenser coils every 6 months; check door seals annually |
| Range/Stove (Dual Fuel) | 15-23 years | Plan replacement at 18-20 years | Clean burners regularly; professional service as needed |
| Dishwasher | 9-12 years | Plan replacement at 10-12 years | Clean filter monthly; run with dishwasher cleaner quarterly |
| Microwave | 9-10 years | Plan replacement at 9-10 years | Clean interior regularly; test door seal annually |

**Your Equipment:** Refrigerator (Entry) Hotpoint - *Expected 10-15 years*; Refrigerator (Kitchen) KitchenAid Built-in - *Expected 13-18 years (premium)*; Range GE Monogram 48" - *Expected 18-23 years (professional-grade)*; Dishwasher - *Expected 10-12 years*; Microwave Sharp Carousel - *Expected 9-10 years*

**Laundry Appliances:**

| Appliance | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|-----------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Washing Machine (Front-load) | 10-14 years | Plan replacement at 12-14 years | Clean gasket monthly; leave door open between uses; check hoses annually |
| Dryer (Electric) | 10-13 years | Plan replacement at 12-13 years | Clean lint trap after every use; clean vent annually |

**Your Equipment:** Washer Maytag MFWN9700SQ1 - *Expected 12-14 years*; Dryer Maytag MEDZ600SD0 - *Expected 12-13 years*

**Electrical & Security Systems:**

| System | Expected Lifespan | Replacement Recommendation | Maintenance Notes |
|--------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Electrical Panel | 25-40 years | Inspect at 25 years; replace if outdated | Professional inspection every 3-5 years |
| Security Alarm System | 10-15 years | Upgrade at 12-15 years | Test monthly; replace batteries annually |
| Router/Modem | 3-5 years | Replace every 4-5 years | Update firmware regularly |
| Irrigation Controller | 5-10 years | Replace at 8-10 years | Check batteries seasonally; test zones annually |

**Your Equipment:** Pushmatic Panels - *Vintage system, consider upgrade*; Square D Panels - *Expected 30-40 years*; Security Alarm Honeywell - *Expected 12-15 years*; Router Zhone - *Expected 4-5 years*; Irrigation Rain Bird - *Expected 8-10 years*

**Replacement Planning Guidelines:**

Replace (rather than repair) when: (1) Repair costs exceed 50% of replacement cost, (2) Appliance is beyond 75% of expected lifespan, (3) Energy efficiency improvements would save significant costs, or (4) Multiple repairs in past 2 years.

**Budget Planning - Estimated Replacement Costs:**
- Water Heaters (2): Every 10-12 years (~$1,500-$2,500 each installed)
- Furnaces (2): Every 15-20 years (~$3,000-$6,000 each installed)
- Refrigerators (2): Every 13-15 years (~$1,500-$8,000 depending on model)
- Range: Every 18-20 years (~$5,000-$15,000 for professional-grade)
- Washer/Dryer: Every 12-13 years (~$1,200-$2,000 for the pair)
- Dishwasher: Every 10-12 years (~$800-$1,500 installed)
- Microwave: Every 9-10 years (~$200-$500)

**Maintenance Schedule Summary:**

**Monthly:** Test security alarm; clean dishwasher filter; clean dryer lint trap; clean washer gasket

**Quarterly:** Clean/replace furnace filters; run dishwasher cleaner cycle; test irrigation zones

**Semi-Annually:** Clean refrigerator condenser coils; check irrigation batteries

**Annually:** Professional furnace service; flush water heater tanks; check water heater anode rods (every 3-5 years); professional alarm service; clean dryer vent; check washer hoses; test GFCI/AFCI breakers; professional electrical inspection (every 3-5 years)

**HVAC Systems:**

|--------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Oil Furnace | 15-20 years | Plan replacement at 18-20 years | Annual professional service required; clean/replace filters quarterly |
| Electric Water Heater | 8-12 years | Plan replacement at 10-12 years | Flush tank annually; check anode rod every 3-5 years; inspect for leaks regularly |
| Thermostat (Programmable) | 10-15 years | Replace when malfunctioning or upgrading HVAC | Replace batteries annually (if applicable) |

**Your Equipment:** Furnace (West Zone) Thermo Pride - *Expected 15-20 years*; Furnace (East Zone) Thermo Pride - *Expected 15-20 years*; Water Heater (Main) Bradford White 50 gal - *Expected 10-12 years*; Water Heater (Basement) Bradford White 50 gal - *Expected 10-12 years*

| Range/Stove (Dual Fuel) | 15-23 years | Plan replacement at 18-20 years | Clean burners regularly; professional service as needed |
| Dishwasher | 9-12 years | Plan replacement at 10-12 years | Clean filter monthly; run with dishwasher cleaner quarterly |
| Microwave | 9-10 years | Plan replacement at 9-10 years | Clean interior regularly; test door seal annually |

**Your Equipment:** Refrigerator (Entry) Hotpoint - *Expected 10-15 years*; Refrigerator (Kitchen) KitchenAid Built-in - *Expected 13-18 years (premium)*; Range GE Monogram 48" - *Expected 18-23 years (professional-grade)*; Dishwasher - *Expected 10-12 years*; Microwave Sharp Carousel - *Expected 9-10 years*

**Laundry Appliances:**

| Washing Machine (Front-load) | 10-14 years | Plan replacement at 12-14 years | Clean gasket monthly; leave door open between uses; check hoses annually |
| Dryer (Electric) | 10-13 years | Plan replacement at 12-13 years | Clean lint trap after every use; clean vent annually |

**Your Equipment:** Washer Maytag MFWN9700SQ1 - *Expected 12-14 years*; Dryer Maytag MEDZ600SD0 - *Expected 12-13 years*

**Electrical & Security Systems:**

|--------|-------------------|---------------------------|-------------------|
| Electrical Panel | 25-40 years | Inspect at 25 years; replace if outdated | Professional inspection every 3-5 years |
| Security Alarm System | 10-15 years | Upgrade at 12-15 years | Test monthly; replace batteries annually |
| Router/Modem | 3-5 years | Replace every 4-5 years | Update firmware regularly |
| Irrigation Controller | 5-10 years | Replace at 8-10 years | Check batteries seasonally; test zones annually |

**Your Equipment:** Pushmatic Panels - *Vintage system, consider upgrade*; Square D Panels - *Expected 30-40 years*; Security Alarm Honeywell - *Expected 12-15 years*; Router Zhone - *Expected 4-5 years*; Irrigation Rain Bird - *Expected 8-10 years*

**Replacement Planning Guidelines:**

Replace (rather than repair) when: (1) Repair costs exceed 50% of replacement cost, (2) Appliance is beyond 75% of expected lifespan, (3) Energy efficiency improvements would save significant costs, or (4) Multiple repairs in past 2 years.

**Budget Planning - Estimated Replacement Costs:**
- Water Heaters (2): Every 10-12 years (~$1,500-$2,500 each installed)
- Furnaces (2): Every 15-20 years (~$3,000-$6,000 each installed)
- Refrigerators (2): Every 13-15 years (~$1,500-$8,000 depending on model)
- Range: Every 18-20 years (~$5,000-$15,000 for professional-grade)
- Washer/Dryer: Every 12-13 years (~$1,200-$2,000 for the pair)
- Dishwasher: Every 10-12 years (~$800-$1,500 installed)
- Microwave: Every 9-10 years (~$200-$500)

**Maintenance Schedule Summary:**

**Monthly:** Test security alarm; clean dishwasher filter; clean dryer lint trap; clean washer gasket

**Quarterly:** Clean/replace furnace filters; run dishwasher cleaner cycle; test irrigation zones

**Semi-Annually:** Clean refrigerator condenser coils; check irrigation batteries

**Annually:** Professional furnace service; flush water heater tanks; check water heater anode rods (every 3-5 years); professional alarm service; clean dryer vent; check washer hoses; test GFCI/AFCI breakers; professional electrical inspection (every 3-5 years)

- **Replacement Cost:** $2,000-$4,000 installed
- **Annual Maintenance:** $100-$200 (inspection and cleaning)
- **Manual:** https://manuals.fire-parts.com/aws-assets/vermont-castings-jefferson-jdv-2820-jefferson_jdv_2820_install-pdf.pdf

- **Panel Model:** QOC-20M Series G1 (QO Load Center)
- **Panel Type:** Main breaker panel with 20 circuit spaces
- **Breaker Type:** Square D QO series (plug-on style)
- **Main Breaker:** Present (top of panel, labeled "MAIN")
- **Location:** Interior wall, recessed installation with custom wood trim surround
- **Total Circuits:** 20 spaces
- **Panel Condition:** Functional, some circuits labeled

- Circuits 10, 12: REC (receptacles/outlets)

- Circuits 14, 16: BASEMENT
- Circuit 18: UNKNOWN
- Other circuits: Not clearly labeled or blank

**Notes:**
- Circuit directory handwritten and partially illegible
- Multiple heating circuits suggest electric heat in addition to gas fireplace
- Recommend creating updated, typed circuit directory
- Panel appears to be properly installed with adequate capacity for cottage use

- **Condition:** Functional, properly installed
- **Photos:** Camp_Kitchen_Electrical_Panel_Circuits.jpg

**Generator Transfer Switch System:**
- **Type:** Manual transfer switch
- **Utility Company:** OPALCO (Orcas Power & Light Cooperative)
- **Generator:** Dayton diesel generator (documented in Generator Shed section)
- **Buildings Served:** Main House, Chalet, Camp Kitchen
- **Transfer Procedure:** Documented step-by-step instructions available
- **Switch Locations:** "House Main Switch #1", "Main Switch on panel #2", "Transfer Switch #3"
- **Operating Instructions:** Complete procedure for switching between OPALCO utility power and generator power
- **Photos:** Generator_Transfer_Switch_Instructions.jpg
- **Critical Note:** Manual transfer switch requires sequential steps to safely switch between utility and generator power

**Transfer Switch Operating Procedure:**

*To switch to generator power:*
1. Start generator
2. Turn off House Main Switch #1
3. Turn off main Switch on panel #2
4. Switch #3 Transfer Switch to GEN.SE (generator)
5. Turn on House Main Switch #1
6. Turn on main switch on panel #2

*To switch back to OPALCO utility power:*
1. Turn off House Main Switch #1
2. Turn off main Switch on panel #2
3. Switch #3 Transfer Switch to OPALCO
4. Turn off generator
5. Turn on House Main Switch #1
6. Turn on main switch on panel #2

- Rinnai tankless water heater (wall-mounted)

- Manual generator transfer switch

- **Electrical:** Square D electrical panel with main disconnect switch (see utility room details below)
- **Heating:** [To be documented]
- **Utility Room:** Dedicated mechanical room with water heater, electrical panels, and master controls (see details below)

**Refrigerator - Amana TX18VL:**
- **Brand/Model:** Amana TX18VL (Whirlpool Corporation)
- **Manufacturing Number:** P1302M
- **Serial Number:** 9709132292
- **Type:** Full-size top-freezer refrigerator
- **Capacity:** Approximately 18 cubic feet total
- **Configuration:** Top freezer, bottom fresh food compartment
- **Finish:** White
- **Door Handles:** White/cream colored
- **Electrical:** 115VAC 60Hz (standard household power)
- **Design Pressure:** 235H5 & 140L5
- **Features:** Ice maker compatible, door storage, crisper drawers, interior lighting (40W bulb)
- **Condition:** Functional, in active use
- **Accessories:** Temperature control/timer device mounted on top, green apron and pink towel hanging on handles
- **Estimated Lifespan:** 10-15 years (typical for top-freezer refrigerators)
- **Replacement Cost:** $600-$1,200 (new similar unit)
- **Parts Availability:** Widely available through PartSelect, Sears Parts Direct, Repair Clinic
- **Common Replacement Parts:** Light bulb (#8009), ice maker (#D7824706Q), door switch (#W11384469), fan motor (#833697)
- **Manufacturer Support:** Amana/Whirlpool, 1-866-319-8402, www.amana.com
- **Photos:** Camp_Kitchen_Refrigerator_Amana_Exterior.jpg, Camp_Kitchen_Refrigerator_Data_Plate.jpg
- **Notes:** Full-size refrigerator appropriate for camp/group kitchen use, adequate capacity for storing food for gatherings and events

**Gas Range - GE Profile Double Oven:**
- **Brand:** GE Profile (premium GE Appliances line)
- **Type:** Free-standing gas double oven range with convection
- **Width:** 30 inches (standard)
- **Finish:** Stainless steel with black glass oven door
- **Cooktop:** 5 sealed gas burners with continuous black porcelain-coated grates
- **Burner Configuration:** Various BTU outputs (typically 5,000-21,000 BTU range)
- **Burner Features:** Sealed burners for easy cleaning, continuous grates for moving heavy pots
- **Oven Type:** Gas double oven (upper and lower ovens)
- **Convection:** Yes (convection fan for even cooking)
- **Total Oven Capacity:** Approximately 6.8 cubic feet combined (typical for double oven models)
- **Oven Window:** Large black glass viewing window
- **Control Panel:** Black glass with stainless steel trim, digital display and numeric keypad
- **Controls:** Bake, Broil, Roast, Cooking Time, Delay Start, Kitchen Timer, Clock, Oven Light
- **Storage Drawer:** Bottom warming/storage drawer with stainless handle
- **Features:** Convection cooking, electronic ignition, self-clean capability, Sabbath mode
- **Gas Connection:** Natural gas or propane (convertible with kit)
- **Electrical:** 120V AC for ignition and controls
- **Condition:** Functional, in active use, well-maintained
- **Estimated Lifespan:** 13-15 years (typical for gas ranges)
- **Replacement Cost:** $1,999-$2,499 (current GE Profile double oven gas ranges)
- **Manufacturer Support:** GE Appliances, www.geappliances.com
- **Photos:** Camp_Kitchen_Stove_GE_Profile_Full.jpg, Camp_Kitchen_Stove_Control_Panel.jpg
- **Notes:** High-quality premium appliance perfect for camp kitchen serving groups. Double oven provides flexibility for cooking multiple dishes simultaneously. Gas cooking preferred for precise temperature control. Convection feature ensures even baking and roasting.

**Utility Room & Mechanical Systems:**

**Water Heater - Rinnai Tankless:**
- **Brand:** Rinnai (leading tankless water heater manufacturer)
- **Type:** Tankless on-demand gas-fired water heater
- **Installation:** Indoor wall-mounted
- **Finish:** Silver/gray metal cabinet
- **Display:** Digital LED showing temperature (35°C / 95°F)
- **Controls:** 4-button digital control panel for temperature adjustment
- **Operation:** On-demand (heats water only when needed, no standby loss)
- **Capacity:** Endless hot water supply (never runs out)
- **Connections:** 3/4" copper water pipes, yellow CSST gas line, 120V electrical
- **Efficiency:** 82-96% thermal efficiency (model-dependent)
- **Flow Rate:** Typically 5.0-11.1 GPM depending on model
- **BTU Input:** 130,000-199,000 BTU/hr (model-dependent)
- **Venting:** Direct vent (vented through wall or roof)
- **Condition:** Clean, well-maintained, functional
- **Estimated Lifespan:** 20+ years with proper maintenance
- **Replacement Cost:** $1,500-$3,500 installed
- **Annual Maintenance:** $150-$250 (descaling service recommended)
- **Energy Savings:** 20-40% vs traditional tank water heater
- **Manufacturer:** Rinnai Corporation, www.rinnai.us
- **Photos:** Camp_Kitchen_Water_Heater_Rinnai_Tankless.jpg
- **Notes:** Perfect for camp kitchen application providing on-demand hot water for groups. Compact wall-mounted design saves floor space. Gas-fired provides fast recovery and high flow rates.

**Electrical System - Master Control Center:**

**Main Disconnect Switch (CRITICAL):**
- **Brand:** Square D
- **Type:** Heavy-duty safety disconnect switch
- **Label:** "MAIN HOUSE DISCONNECT" (blue label)
- **Function:** Master shutoff for Main House, Chalet, Camp Kitchen, and Picnic Shelter
- **Switch:** ON/OFF toggle switch
- **Location:** Utility room wall
- **Conduit:** Metal flex conduit connections
- **Warning Labels:** Square D danger/warning labels
- **Photos:** Camp_Kitchen_Main_Disconnect_Switch.jpg
- **Critical Note:** This is the MASTER DISCONNECT for the entire shared electrical system serving four buildings

**Main Electrical Panel:**
- **Brand:** Square D
- **Configuration:** Dual-column breaker panel
- **Total Spaces:** Approximately 40 circuit spaces (20 per column)
- **Breaker Type:** Square D QO series (plug-on style)
- **Circuit Directory:** Handwritten directory on right side
- **Label:** "PELGRO" visible at top
- **Circuits Include:** Main, Pelgro, Water Heater, Water Yard, Gas Outlet, Pelgro Outlet, Lights, Outlets, Tent, Heat, and more
- **Condition:** Functional, properly installed
- **Photos:** Camp_Kitchen_Electrical_Panel_Circuits.jpg

**Generator Transfer Switch System:**
- **Type:** Manual transfer switch
- **Utility Company:** OPALCO (Orcas Power & Light Cooperative)
- **Generator:** Dayton diesel generator (documented in Generator Shed section)
- **Buildings Served:** Main House, Chalet, Camp Kitchen
- **Transfer Procedure:** Documented step-by-step instructions available
- **Switch Locations:** "House Main Switch #1", "Main Switch on panel #2", "Transfer Switch #3"
- **Operating Instructions:** Complete procedure for switching between OPALCO utility power and generator power
- **Photos:** Generator_Transfer_Switch_Instructions.jpg
- **Critical Note:** Manual transfer switch requires sequential steps to safely switch between utility and generator power

**Transfer Switch Operating Procedure:**

*To switch to generator power:*
1. Start generator
2. Turn off House Main Switch #1
3. Turn off main Switch on panel #2
4. Switch #3 Transfer Switch to GEN.SE (generator)
5. Turn on House Main Switch #1
6. Turn on main switch on panel #2

*To switch back to OPALCO utility power:*
1. Turn off House Main Switch #1
2. Turn off main Switch on panel #2
3. Switch #3 Transfer Switch to OPALCO
4. Turn off generator
5. Turn on House Main Switch #1
6. Turn on main switch on panel #2

**Utility Room Equipment Summary:**
- Rinnai tankless water heater (wall-mounted)
- Square D main disconnect switch (master shutoff)
- Square D electrical panel (40-space)
- Manual generator transfer switch
- Pressure tank (visible in photos)
- Fire extinguisher
- White walls, organized installation
- Photos: Camp_Kitchen_Utility_Room.jpg

**Use & Function:**
- Recreational cooking and food preparation facility
- Likely used for outdoor gatherings, picnics, and events
- Part of property's recreational amenities
- Complements outdoor picnic shelter
- Enables large-group food preparation away from main house

**Maintenance Notes:**
- Building appears well-maintained
- Natural setting requires regular landscaping maintenance
- Moss management on surrounding ground and trees
- Garden beds maintained with seasonal plantings

subsections.title: Electrical Systems
subsections.content:
#### Utility Service - Transformer & Metering
- **Service Type:** Underground (from pad-mounted transformer)
- **Transformer Type:** Pad-mounted utility transformer (utility-owned)
- **Transformer Location:** Custom green wooden enclosure near Camp Kitchen area
- **Transformer Condition:** Functional but weathered, debris accumulation on top
- **Transformer Access:** Utility-only (secured/locked)
- **Warning Labels:** Orange high-voltage warning labels present
- **Metering:** Digital electric meter
- **Meter Location:** Wall-mounted on green wooden structure adjacent to transformer
- **Meter Base:** Gray weatherproof meter base
- **Buildings Served by This Meter:** Main House, Chalet, Camp Kitchen, Picnic Shelter (shared metering point)
- **Custom Enclosures:** Two green wooden enclosures with decorative scalloped tops (houses transformer and meter)
- **Enclosure Design:** Matches green paint scheme of Camp Kitchen building
- **Photos:** Transformer_Pad_Mounted.jpg, Electric_Meter_Digital.jpg, Transformer_Meter_Enclosures_Exterior.jpg

**Important Notes:**
- This is a **shared metering point** serving four buildings on one meter
- Transformer and meter enclosures need debris cleaning (fir needles accumulation)
- Custom wooden enclosures provide aesthetic screening while maintaining utility access
- Pacific Northwest environment requires regular maintenance to prevent moisture damage

sections.title: Maintenance & Operations
sections.content:
### Seasonal Maintenance Checklist

#### Spring (March - May)
- [ ] Inspect roofs and gutters on all six homes for winter damage
- [ ] Service HVAC systems in all six homes
- [ ] Check and repair fences
- [ ] Inspect and repair roads/driveways
- [ ] Start irrigation system
- [ ] Service lawn and garden equipment
- [ ] Inspect all buildings for damage
- [ ] Check well and water systems for all homes
- [ ] Test all septic systems
- [ ] Fertilize pastures/fields
- [ ] Change HVAC filters in all homes
- [ ] [Add your tasks]

#### Summer (June - August)
- [ ] Mow and maintain trails
- [ ] Monitor pond levels
- [ ] Check irrigation system regularly
- [ ] Inspect for invasive species
- [ ] Maintain fire breaks
- [ ] Service equipment as needed
- [ ] Monitor livestock water sources
- [ ] [Add your tasks]

#### Fall (September - November)
- [ ] Winterize irrigation system
- [ ] Clean gutters on all six homes
- [ ] Service heating systems in all six homes
- [ ] Prepare equipment for winter storage
- [ ] Harvest hay (if applicable)
- [ ] Inspect and repair all structures before winter
- [ ] Stock winter supplies for all homes
- [ ] Drain outdoor water lines at all homes
- [ ] Change HVAC filters in all homes
- [ ] Check all water heaters
- [ ] [Add your tasks]

#### Winter (December - February)
- [ ] Monitor heating systems in all six homes
- [ ] Keep roads/driveways clear to all homes
- [ ] Check for ice dams on all six homes
- [ ] Monitor livestock shelters
- [ ] Inspect all buildings for storm damage after events
- [ ] Check that all homes have adequate heat
- [ ] Monitor vacant homes for issues
- [ ] Plan spring projects
- [ ] [Add your tasks]

### Monthly Tasks
- [ ] Check all buildings for issues
- [ ] Test generator (if applicable)
- [ ] Inspect fences
- [ ] Check water systems
- [ ] [Add your tasks]

### Annual Tasks
- [ ] Property tax payment
- [ ] Insurance renewal
- [ ] Septic system pumping (as scheduled)
- [ ] Well water testing
- [ ] Chimney cleaning (if applicable)
- [ ] Tree trimming/removal as needed
- [ ] Equipment annual service
- [ ] [Add your tasks]

### Property Documents

### Applicable Codes & Regulations

**San Juan County Unified Development Code**
- **Primary Code:** San Juan County Code Chapter 18.30 - Land Use Designations
- **Section 18.30.040:** Land Use Table for Rural, Resource, and Special Land Use Designations
- **Online Access:** https://www.codepublishing.com/WA/SanJuanCounty/
- **Purpose:** Governs all land use activities, development, and permits on the property

**Key Regulatory Chapters:**
- **Chapter 18.30 SJCC:** Land Use Designations (defines FO and RFF designations)
- **Chapter 18.40 SJCC:** Performance and Use-Specific Standards
- **Chapter 18.60 SJCC:** Development Standards (setbacks, building requirements)
- **Chapter 18.70 SJCC:** Land Division and Boundary Line Adjustments
- **Chapter 18.80 SJCC:** Permit Procedures and Review Processes
- **Chapter 18.50 SJCC:** Shoreline Master Program (applies to waterfront parcels)

**Land Use Designations on Property:**
- **FOR (Forest Resource):** All 7 parcels - Allows residential, forestry, agriculture, resource management
- **Rural Forest (Shoreline Buffer):** 200-foot buffer from top of bank on waterfront parcels - More restrictive use regulations apply within shoreline jurisdiction

**Permit Requirements:**
- Building permits required for all structures
- Land use permits required for certain activities (refer to SJCC 18.30.040 table)
- Shoreline permits required for development near water
- Critical areas review may be required

**Conservation Easements:**
- All 7 parcels have conservation easements ("TGW CONS ESMT" in legal descriptions)
- Easements may restrict development, land division, and certain uses
- Easement documents should be reviewed before any major development
- Contact: San Juan County Land Bank or easement holder for specific restrictions

**Contact Information:**
- **San Juan County Community Development Department**
- Phone: (360) 378-2354
- Website: https://www.sanjuancountywa.gov/
- Address: 135 Rhone St, Friday Harbor, WA 98250
